caption_original:
On this day in 1966 four Caterpillar tractors began dragging the 1,300-ton S.S. Klondike II from the Whitehorse shipyards to her current location next to the river at the far end of town. Over eight tons of Palmolive Princess Snow Flake soap lubricated the steel cradle and wooden skids on which she moved. It took 5 weeks to complete the move! Now restored to her original 1937 appearance, the S.S. Klondike was designated a National Historic Site in 1967.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

On the west side of Newfoundland's Great Northern Peninsula, you‚Äôll find the crossroads of 6000 years of human history at Port au Choix National Historic Site. Discover one of North America‚Äôs most fascinating archaeological finds amid a rugged coastline of unique limestone barrens, forests and bays. Visit ancient burial sites, settlements and view original artifacts, from slate spears to harpoons.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
During the mid-16th century, large numbers of right and bowhead whales drew whalers from the Basque region of Spain and France to the Strait of Belle Isle, where they established a major whaling port at Red Bay. For some 70 years, Basque whalers made the dangerous, month-long journey across the Atlantic to hunt whales and produce the oil that lit the lamps of Europe. See original Basque artifacts, remains, and restored chalupa at Red Bay National Historic Site in Newfoundland. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

We‚Äôre celebrating #InuvialuitDay! We‚Äôre proud to cooperatively manage the beautiful Tuktut Nogait NP with the Inuvialuit. The landscape and wildlife of the 18,890 sq km national park is seen by those privileged few willing to travel 170 kilometres north of the Arctic Circle. The landscape features rolling hills, three major rivers, steep canyons, waterfalls, rare Bluenose west caribou and the continent‚Äôs fiercest predators. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

Roughly 30 kilometres southeast of Montr√©al, Fort Chambly National Historic Site rises proudly at the foot of the Richelieu River rapids. Built in 1711 to defend the colony, this stone fortification was preceded by three wooden forts. The fort has preserved the main elements of its original architecture so that you truly feel like you‚Äôre walking in the steps of a French infantryman from the 18th century.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!
